Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Simulation-Based Training for Cerebral Aneurysm Coiling

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at the University of Western Ontario.

Participants.evidence: Participants were 12 novice medical students with minimal endovascular skills.

Intervention.evidence: They underwent simulation-based training using the ANGIO Mentor Express simulator. The intervention involved diagnostic cerebral angiography (CA) training followed by aneurysm coiling training over six sessions.

Objective.evidence: The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of simulation-based training in developing technical skills for cerebral aneurysm coiling among novice medical students.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was procedural task time, measured over the training period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was not applicable as all participants received the intervention.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The average procedural time decreased from 42 to 24 minutes (p < 0.05).

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by Oleksiy Zaika, Roy Eagleson, and Sandrine de Ribaupierre.
